text: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton
arrived in Afghanistan one day before
President Hamid Karzai will be sworn in
for another term one thing she'll do on
behalf of the United States is urged
President Karzai to route out the
corruption in his government and that's
going to be a tough job I'm Jane borna
Meyer i'm here with kraut leur of the
times foreign desk who's handling our
story for tomorrow kirk destruct
describe to us why what makes this job
so difficult for President Karzai well
for President Karzai he he was elected
in the first place now because he struck
a lot of alliances with allies around
the country and he's promised quite a
bit of stock now in his new government
so he needs to follow through on this
promises in order to keep himself in
power and in favor with people around
the country but for the Americans that's
not going to promise good governance and
it's not going to promise government
that's not corrupt so it's going to be a
bit of a tug of war so how does
President Karzai route out corrupt
officials I mean what kind of authority
does he have to do that and and if there
are so many of them I mean where does he
even begin he could start with his
cabinet and he could have a bit of a
cabinet shake-up or he could look at his
regional governors so I think will be a
lot of attention paid by journalists
international community officials in
Washington as to what his early cabinet
appointments are and if he takes out
certain key people in important
ministries with unsavory reputations and
are there a couple of examples of people
who stand out in your mind as targets
maybe for President Karzai well I mean
there are certain ministries that are
very very important but I mean already
it's he's come under a lot of pressure
before the election to kind of distance
himself or replaces his first vice
president general dostum but he seems
very unlikely to do that dostum has a
very sketchy track record of human
rights abuses from earlier Afghan Wars
but he did bring President Karzai a lot
of support particularly in the north of
the country so he's beholden to him now
and it seems that he's probably likely
to keep long
and how does the United States actually
measure progress and to what extent does
us support depend on that progress well
the progress is very important I mean
American officials are likely to set
certain benchmarks for him in order to
also maintain support for the war in
Congress but you know for President
Karzai I mean over time I guess is where
we're going to have to see whether his
management of the country is any better
for the Americans it's very important
because they can have a battle strategy
which the Obama administration is
working on now but unless the government
can actually deliver effective services
to people and gain the trust of Afghans
then there's really not a second leg to
the stool there
